citation.article-title: Desulfovibrio vietnamensis sp. nov., a halophilic sulfate-reducing bacterium from Vietnamese oil fields.

p.s: Desulfovibrio vietnamensis (viet.na.men.sis, L. adj. vietnamensis, from Vietnam, referring to the country of isolation)
Vibrio-shaped cells of 0.8–1 μm in diameter and 2.5–3 μm in length.
Motile by a single polar flagella.
The pH range is 5–10; optimum growth occurs at pH 7.5.
The temperature range is 12–45°C; optimum growth occurs at 37°C.
The salinity range is 0–10%; optimum growth occurs in the presence of 5% NaCl.
Strictly anaerobic; reduces sulfate, sulfite, thiosulfate and fumarate with production of sulfide.
Nitrate is not used as an electron acceptor.
Substrates which are oxidized by sulfate reduction are lactate, pyruvate, malate, formate, fumarate, ethanol, glycerol.
The G + C content of the DNA is 60.6 mol% (as determined by high-performance liquid chromatography).
Susceptible to ampicillin, chloramphenicol, erythromycin, novobiocin and tetracycline.
Not susceptible to anisomycin, bacitracin and streptomycin.
Habitat: production fluids from Vietnamese offshore oil fields.
The type strain is G3 100, which has been deposited in the DSMZ (Braunschweig, Germany) as DSM 10520.
